title: FUZZY ALMOST PRECONTINUOUS MAPPINGS
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to introduce a new type of weakend fuzzy continuity called fuzzy almost precontinuous and investigate properties of it.

title: Enhanced transport of salbutamol sulphate through rat skin via lontophoresis
abstract: The effects of various factors like pH of the donor solution, current density and permeation enhancers on the passive and iontophoretic transport of salbutamol sulphate (SS) have been studied through rat skin. The transport of the drug was greater during iontophoresis in comparison to passive diffusion at all pHs studied. Maximum steady state flux (26.38 g/cm/hr) was found at pH ll during cathodal iontophoresis. However, the fraction change in flux was maximum at pH 7.4 during anodal iontophoresis. It was observed that an increase in the current density resulted in the increase of both cathodal and anodal iontophoretic flux. Permeation enhancer, dimethylsulphoxide (DMSO), increased the permeability coefficient of SS across the rat skin. One of the most important applications of this study is the possibility of enhancing and controlling the transdermai delivery of salbutamol sulphate by iontophoresis.

title: Morphogenetic studies on some economic medicinal plants
abstract: India, with approximately 8% of world's biodiversity is bestowed with rich natural resources, diverse ecological conditions and a long practice of traditional farming systems consistent with their ethnic diversity and ancient civilization. Out of the 1500 species identified 1100 species are used in different systems of medicines and out of these, 600-700 species are used in India, mainly by the indigenous industries.More immediately, however, the availability of medicinal plants is already under serious threat. Around 95% of the medicinal plants used by the Indian industry today are collected from the wild. Less than 20 species of plants are under commercial cultivation. Over 70% of the plant collections involve destructive harvesting because of the use of parts like roots, bark, wood, stem and the whole plants (in case of herbs). This poses a definite threat to the genetic stocks and to the diversity of medicinal plants. Conservation of medicinal plant species is possible through either in situ or ex situ means, or preferably through a combination of both.

title: Tolerant (UV-HS ‘) Mutant of the Unicellular Cyanobacterium Anacystis nidtzlans
abstract: UV~ B and heat shock induced changes in some selected photochemical processes have been studied in the wild type Anacyst ‘fs m'dur'ans and its UV-HS'mutant strain. The UV—HS ‘mutant strain grew reasonably well even in the presence of DCMU and had 2.5 fold higher growth rate to that. of its wild type counterpart. Furthermore, the UV-HS’mutant strain lost fluorescent emission spectrum between 650-660 nm due to mutagenesis. However, no significant UV—HS-induced changes in the peaks of both chlorophyll a (Chl a) and phycobilisome (PB) emission spectra were ob—served in UV—HSt mutant strain. In contrast, sig-nificant UV—HS induced reduction and 6-8 nm shifting in the emission peaks of both Ch! a and PB were noticed in wild type strain. Whereas, the wild type strain exhibited a dose dependent reduction in 14CO2 fixation and photosynthetic 0: evolution, the UV—HSt mutant strain, in contrast …

title: Physiological Analysis of Traditional Tall and Improved Semi-tall Rice Cultivars
abstract: MORPHO-PHYSIOLOGICAL analysis of improved semi-tall (Pusa 169, IR 72 and Pusa Basmati 1) and traditional tall (Basmati 370 and Karnal Local) rice cultivars grown at moderate soil fertility level revealed that semi-tall improved cultivars were superior to traditional tall basmati cultivars in panicle bearing tillers, grain yield, harvest index, economic productivity, foliage efficiency and post anthesis CGR, biomass production and leaf weight depletion coefficient. The traditional tall basmati cultivars were better than semi-tall improved in LAI, leaf area per tiller, leaf size, total biomass production at flowering and grains per panicle, biological yield, pre-anthesis CGR and dry matter production and post-anthesis stem weight coefficient. The improved and traditional cultivars however did not show much variation in SLW, SLA and foliage efficiency for total biomass production. The traditional basmati cultivars though produced about 25-30 per cent greater biomass, manifested lower grain yield than semi-tall mainly due to poor biomass transformation into grain under severe lodging. The economic yield of traditional tall cultivars, however, was at par semi-tall improved ones when protected from lodging

title: Acute Toxicity of Neem Oil to Juvenile Fish Cirrhinus mrigala(Ham.)
abstract: A study was carried out to investigate the acute toxicity of neem oil against fingerlings of the fish Cirrhinus mrigala. Neem oil was found to be highly toxic to fish. The LC sub(50) values ranging 0.245 to 0.109 ml/liter for 24--96 hours were calculated for neem oil. No mortality was observed in control.

title: HPLC Estimation Method Of A New Spermicidal And Anti HIV Compound 1-(4-Methoxy phenyl), 5-Piperidino Penta-1, 4-Diene-3-One In Its Dosage Form
abstract: HPLC method for the estimation of a new spermicidal and anti HIV agent, 1-(4-methoxy phenyl), 5-piperidino penta-1,4-diene-3-one. Tartarate [CDRI compound 87/132] in bulk samples and formulations is described. The calibration curve was linear in the range of 50-500 mg/ml. This method was used for the estimation of this compound in its formulations.

title: Indirect somatic embryogenesis from leaf segments in mango (Mangifera indica L.) AMRAPALI
abstract: Somatic tissues like leaf, petiole etc. which are available all the year round, can be an ideal material to conduct genetic transformation experiments in mango via partical bomardment or by Agrobacterium sp. We report here a protocol for somatic embryogenesis from leaf tissue in mango cv. Amrapali, which is considered highly recalcitrant. Callusing followed by embryogenesis has been achieved from leaf segment of 2-year-old, greenhouse grown plants. The sprouts appearing on beheaded stock (30-days) were covered with black perforated polythene sheet for etiolation (45 days). Three types of leaf explants, i.e. apex, section with midrib and leaf bases with portion of petiole, were agitated in a solution of poly vinyl polypyrrolidone (400 mg/L) + 20 g/L sucrose for 2 hr prior to inoculation. The explants were then inoculated on B5 or WPM (macro salts) + full strength MS (micro salts+organics)+60 g/L sucrose+400 mg/L glutamine+casein hydrolysate (200 mg/L)+L-ascorbic acid (50 mg/L) alongwith 2, 4-D (0 to 5 mg/L) and Zeatin (0.2 or 0.5 mg/L) and Zeatin (0.2 or 0.5 mg/L). Callusing was best (69.4 percent) on the medium (B5+MS) containing 2,4-D (4.0 mg/L+Zeatin (0.5 mg/L) on the leaf segments taken from middle portion of lamina with midrib. Callus multiplication and formation of globular embryoid-like structures was achieved on liquid medium with 2, 4-D (0.5 mg/L) and AgNO3 (10 micro M) on a shaker kept in dark (120 rpm). Globular embryos germinated on solid medium devoid of growth regulators. Plantlet development occured on filter paper bridge dipped in liquid medium containing IBA (1.0 mg/L).

title: Assay Methods For A New Analgesic Enkephalin Analogue CDRI Compound No. 82/205
abstract: HPLC and TLC-densitometric methods for the estimation of L-tyrosyl-D-alanyl-glycyl-L-N-methyl pyhenyl alanyl glycinyl-N-isopropyl amide [compound 82/205] in bulk samples and formulations are described. The calibration curves were linear in the range of 4-40 mg/ml for HPLC and in the range of 0.5 - 20 mg for TLC-densitometric method.

title: Radiomodifying effects of the DNA binding ligand Hoechst 33342 in Ehrlich ascites tumor cells in vitro
abstract: [en] The removal of free (and possibly loosely bound to DNA) H-342 was faster when cells were irradiated (D= 5 Gy) after an incubation with the dye for 1 h as compared to the un-irradiated cells. Pre-treatment with H-342 for 1 h decreased gamma-ray (D= 5 Gy) induced DNA damage in a concentration dependent manner, but did not significantly alter the rate of DNA repair. This was accompanied by a decrease in the rate of cell cycle progression and micronuclei formation, studied at a H-342 concentration of 20 μM. Under these conditions (20 μM and 1 h) H-342 marginally enhanced the DNA unwinding in un-irradiated cells, which returned to the control values in less than 60 min. after removing the ligand and did not induce micronuclei formation

title: Radioprotection by the DNA binding ligands in whole body irradiated mice
abstract: [en] In the present work, the radioprotective effects of Hoechst-33342 (H-342) and Hoechst-33258 (H-258) have been investigated in whole body irradiated strain-A and Balb/c mice at various dose rates of 60 Co gamma-rays (0.01 to 0.05 Gy/min.; total dose= 2.5 to 10 Gy). Biodistribution of iv administered Hoechst dyes and their effects on cell cycle kinetics were studied by flow cytometry, while cytogenetic damage to the bone marrow cells (chromosomal aberrations, micronuclei formation and DNA content dispersion), erythropoiesis and animal survival were investigated as parameters of radiation response

title: Contribution of W {sup {plus_minus}} H {sup {minus_plus}} Z {sub i} vertices to anomalous magnetic dipole and electric quadrupole moments of the W boson in the extra U (1 …
abstract: W {sup {plus_minus}} H {sup {minus_plus}} Z {sub i}(i= 1, 2) vertices available exclusively in the extra U (1) superstring-inspired model have been utilized to evaluate the WW-{gamma} vertex contribution at the one loop level. The expressions so obtained have been used to estimate the anomalous magnetic dipole moment ({Delta} k {sub WZ {sub i} H}) and electric quadrupole moment ({Delta} Q {sub WZ {sub i} H}) of the W {sup+} boson. The contribution of the Z {sub 2} WW vertex is also added to these values. The resulting values in the unit of ({minus}{alpha}/{pi}) when the Z {sub 2} mass varies from 555 to 620 GeV have the following ranges: for m {sub t (CDF)}= 175.6 GeV,{Delta} k {sub [U (1)]}, from 25.402 to 41.559,{Delta} Q {sub [U (1)]}, from 6.886 to 10.858; for m {sub t (D0)}= 169GeV,{Delta} k {sub [U (1)]}, from 20.821 to 34.121,{Delta} Q {sub [U (1)]}, from 5.738 to 9.033. These are larger than the standard model radiative correction contributions but an order of magnitude smaller than those predicted by the composite model of Abbott and Farhi.

title: B74-Expression of Heterosis for Yield and Yield Traits in Indian Wheat Crosses under Drill Sown Condition
abstract: Methods One hundred intervarietal crosses were developed during the 1994-95 and 1995-97 wheat crop seasons, utilizing diverse commercial wheat varieties of northern India. The parental varieties and their F1 populations were sown in three replications in a randomized block design during two consecutive crop seasons (1995-96 and 1996-97). Sowing was done by hand using the drill sowing method. Each plot consisted of two rows of 3 m with a 30 cm row spacing. Check varieties HUW 206 and HUW 214 were also planted for comparison. The recommended package of practices was followed to raise a normal healthy crop. Whole plots were harvested separately to measure number of effective tillers per meter length, number of grains per spike, thousand grain weight (g), and grain yield (g). Heterosis expressed as percentage increase or decrease of F, over the better parent (heterobeltiosis) and check parent (standard heterosis) was calculated according to the methods suggested by Hays et aI.(1955).Results Several crosses showed heterosis over checks for yield and associated yield components. For grain yield, the best hybrid was CPAN 3048 x HUW 206 followed by CPAN 4007 x HUW 206, BW 362 x HUW 234 and HUW 2005 x K 9107. However, only the first two crosses showed a heterosis for grain yield over the check parent HUW 243 of more than 20%--the accepted minimum for commercial exploitation under the field conditions.

title: A CASE STUDY ON ROUGHENING OF PCC SURFACE FOR A RIGID OVERLAY
abstract: This paper discusses some experiments conducted at Gorakhpur, India, to find an economically viable solution to the problem of roughening of PCC surface, which had become critical to the process of resurfacing an airfield runway. A total area of 54,000 square m had to be roughened within 120 days at most. The three trials used:(1) a pneumatic jack hammer;(2) a modified terrazzo cutting machine; and (3) an improvised trolley-mounted pneumatic chipping hammer. During the trials, disadvantages observed in the mechanical roughening systems included starting problems and defects of compressors, defects in pneumatic tools, and blunting and breaking of chisels. There were also trials of manual roughening methods, using an axe-type chiselling hammer and a well-designed chipping hammer. It was found that both mechanical and manual methods of roughening produced an excellent roughened PCC surface. The quality of roughening was so high that, with sufficient care, a very effective bond could be created between old and new concrete. Manual roughening was found to much cheaper than mechanical roughening, and employed many previously unemployed workers for the duration of the project.

title: Studies on Herbicide Residue in Post-harvested Soils of Lentil under Irrigated Condition
abstract: Residual roxicity ofherbicides on the succeeding crops poses a threat to the. wide use of chemical weed control. Bioassay studies are used as an alternative method for quick detection ofthe biological response ofa living plant to a herbicide and to quantify its concentration in a substrate. The cucumber has been used as sensitive seed in estimating herbicides such as pendimethalin and metolachlor residues in soil (Saxena et al., 1992) Therefore, the present investigation was undertaken to study the herbicides residue in the post-harvested soils of lentil by using cucumber as bioassay plant for pendimethalin and metolachlor. The present investigation was carried out at Agronomy Research Farmofthe University during rabi seasons of 1993-94 and 1994-95 in a randomized block design with four replications. The soil of the experimental field was silty loam in texture ofpoor, medium and rich in nitrogen, phosphorus …

title: Geophysical study of bedrock nature and behaviour at Chatra dam site, Dehradun and Uttarkashi districts, Uttar Pradesh
abstract: The paper presents the results of electrical resistivity and seismic refraction surveys conducted for delineation of nature and depth of bedrock before constructing a 200 m high rock filled darn-across the river Tons for generating 80 MW hydroelectric power in Chatra area (30 58'27N) 77 56'28E), Dehradun and Uttarkashi districts, UP Characteristic P-wave velocity and electrical resistivity values of the quartz-mica schist/massive quartzite/bedrock have led to its successful delineation. Appreciably larger depths varying from 30 m to 60 m in the flood plain and maximum overburden thickness of the order of 80 m over terraces near the road gutting at the proposed dam axis have been inferred in contrast with the exposures on both the banks. The bedrock profile along the dam axis shows two depressions possibly linked to palacoglacial activities in the area, one of which is along the Chatra Gad and the other along the dam axis. No bedrock intersection down to the depth of 44 m in the drill hole very accurately corroborates the interpreted depths between 44 m and 52.6 m in the river bed.―.

title: Cretaceous and Middle Eocene radiolaria from ejected sediments of mud volcanoes of Baratang Island in Andaman Sea of the northeastern Indian Ocean
abstract: Radiolarians from seven samples of ejected sediments of mud volcanoes of Baratang Island in the Andaman Sea provide additional evidence for the presence of Cretaceous and Middle Eocene strata beneath the Island.  A general NNE-SSW alignment of the mud volcanoes suggests the structural control for their occurrence due to regional tectonics.

title: Effect of methods of harvesting on storage behaviour of mango (Hangifera indica L.) CVS Hallika and Amrapali
abstract: Experiment was undertaken to compare the storage behaviour of physiologically mature fruits of cvs. Mallika and Amrapali harvested with and without stalk. The fruits were washed with water, graded by density gradation method and kept in cardboard cartons using paper lining and stored at ambient conditions and different parameters were studied on 0, 6, 10, 12 and 14th day of storage. Fruits of both the cultivars harvested without stalk released the latex at the point of detachment of stalk which caused dull appearance of fruits in the storage. There was a gradual reduction in Vitamin 'e' and acidity during storage but with a slower rate in fruits harvested with stalk. Spoilage was mainly due to Diplodia natalensis and loss due to it was more in fruits harvested without stalk. Firmness and organoleptic quality retained for longer period in fruits harvested with stalk than those harvested without stalk in both the cultivars.

title: Melting of woods metal in glycerol water bath
abstract: Continuous in situ weight measurements have been made to study melting of spherical samples of Wood's metal in glycerol-water bath at various bath viscosities and temperatures. The concept of three stages of melting-heating, softening and melting has been invoked to determine the combined heat-transfer coefficient even when the onset of melting is not known. The experimental results agree well with the heat-transfer correlation given by the equation Nu sub D =1+0.6(Gr sub D ) exp 1/4 Pr exp 1/3 .

title: Case control study of Electrocardiographic changes in pregnant women
abstract: Pregnancy causes significant haemodynamic changes and imposes stress on the cardiovascular system. Many healthy women develop signs and symptoms of cardiovascular overload during pregnancy. Knowledge of established normal changes in EKG during normal pregnancy is important. The aim of our study was to detect any early damage to myocardium during pregnancy with the help of electrocardiography. Total of 20 pregnant and 20 non pregnant women were studied. The most significant change observed in ECG was T wave inversion with odds ratio 7.43 (95%. Cl= 1.49 to 41.00. P= 0.005). Stratified analysis showed that there was no confounding role of age in the relationship of T wave inversion and ECG findings.
